resources.string: You have to grant Storage permission
Turn on GPS or network location
T-UI is busy, wait until the execution finishes or use the command \"ctrlc\"

Do you like my work? Rate on Play Store (command: >>rate) or offer me a coffee (command: >>donate). Thank you for using T-UI.

You can disable this message in >>tuisettings
Lock the screen on double tap
There was a problem while connecting to your device camera

Print the list of commands, or info about a command 
Usage: 
help [command] 

Example: 
help exit
Exit from tuixt (changes won\'t be saved)
Can\'t use this feature on your Android version
Cant\'t write here. It\'s a file
You can\'t write or delete this file
Couldn\'t stop the player. Force stop t-ui from settings
Music folder doesn\'t exist, or doesn\'t contain audio files.\nYou should set the right path in settings.txt
Command not found.\nTry to use \">>help\" or \">>tutorial\"

Francesco Andreuzzi (Italy)
	-> Programmer 

Luke Winward
	-> Design & Testing 


Open Source Libraries: 
CompareString
write your SMS or nothing to abort

Manager your aliases 

Usage: 
-add -> add a new alias 
-rm -> remove an existing alias 
-ls -> list your aliases 
-file -> open alias.xml 

Example: 
>>alias -add bip echo beeeeeep 
>>alias -rm bip

Manage your apps 

Usage: 
>>apps [option] [app name] 

-lshidden -> show hidden apps 
-show -> show an hidden application 
-hide -> hide an application 
-ps -> show Google Play Store page for this app 
-st -> show Settings details for this app 
-frc -> force t-ui to open this app 
-file -> open apps.xml 
no option -> list your apps 

Example: 
>>apps -st T-UI

Perform a call to someone or print your contacts 
Usage: call [number] OR [name] (if you don't specify a number or a name you will get the list of your contacts) 

>>call James

Manage your config files. 
Usage: 
>>config [option] [file OR config_entry] [*value] 

-set -> set the value of a config node 
-open -> open a config file 

Example: 
>>config -set bg_color #ff0000aa 
>>config -open suggestions.xml

Copy one or more files to a folder 
Usage: 
>>[su] cp [files] [folder] 

Example: 
>>su cp fool.txt fool2.png myFolder 
>>cp myFile.txt myFolder
Toggle mobile data. Will always turn off if WiFi is active
Print the list of commands, or info about a command \nUsage: \n>>help [command]

Move one or more files to a folder 
Usage: 
>>[su] mv [files] [folder] 

>>su mv fool.txt fool2.png myFolder 
>>mv fool.txt myFolder
Play the next track in the queue
Help T-UI with a positive rate (or negative, I don\'t know)\t;)
Restart t-ui and load modified values

Remove a file: 
Usage: 
>>[su] rm [files] 

Example: 

>>su rm fool.txt fool2.png 
>>rm Downloads/fool.txt

Search something somewhere 
Usage: 
search [option] something 

-g -> (Google Search) 
-p -> (Google Play Store) 
-f -> (Files) 
-y -> (YouTube) 

Example: 
>>search -p T-UI
Get infos about battery charge, wifi status and mobile data
Print informations about the current track
Print all of the tracks in your music folder

Usage: 
t>>tui [option] 

-rm -> remove t-ui 
-about -> show info about the developer and the current version

Uninstall an application 
Usage: 
>>uninstall appName OR packageName 

Example: 
>>uninstall dropbox

Send an SMS. 
Usage: 
>>sms [contact name] OR [phone number] {newline} 
>>[text] 

Example: 
>>sms John Smith 
>>Hi John, I need to talk you about T-UI, it's a fantastic launcher!

Manage your notifications. 
Usage: 
notifications [option] [appName] [*optional* color] 

-inc -> include an application 
-exc -> exclude an appliation 
-clr -> set the color to be used for the application 
-file -> open notifications.xml 

Example: 

notifications -inc Clock 
notifications -clr Settings #FF0000

Manage your contacts. 
Usage: 
cntcts [option] [*optional* contact] 

-ls -> list your contacts 
-show -> show details about a contact 
-new -> create a new contact 
-edit -> edit an existing contact 
-rm -> remove a contact 

Example: 

cntcts -edit James Pike 
cntcts -new
Close T-UI and reset launcher preferences

Open a file with the default application 
Usage: 
>>open [pathToFile] 

Example: 
>>open docs/fool.txt

Print a list of the files in a directory 
Usage: 
>>ls [directory] 

Example: 
>>ls Downloads

string-array.name: tutorial_help
string-array.item: 11help gives you information about commands that comes with T-UI. click on the input area on the bottom of the screen and type \"help\".
11\"help\" has also an other important feature: it works like Linux\'s man, therefore it tells you how to use a command. For example:

string-array.name: tutorial_apps
string-array.item: 11you can launch an app typing its name (or package name) in the input area. For example

11you should also know something about the command \"apps\", which lets you know what apps are installed on your device and provides some shortcuts (mostly to Play Store and Settings) \nTherefore, to learn something about this command:

string-array.name: tutorial_usefulcommands
string-array.item: 11you can call a contact of yours with the command \"call\"
11if you want to remove an app from your device use the command \"uninstall\"
11you can also use rm, cp and mv for file-management
11use \"open\" to view files saved on your phone
11use the command \"clear\" to clean the screen, and \"restart\" to reboot T-UI (and apply setting changes)

string-array.name: tutorial_oscommands
string-array.item: 11you can toggle your WI-FI connection with the command \"wifi\"
11the command \"flash\" lets you turn on or off the flashlight in no time
11there are many commands like these, for example:

string-array.name: tutorial_tuixt
string-array.item: 11the release 5.0 introduced tuixt, the built-in text editor of T-UI. you can start it with this command
01the file can also be non existent, in that case tuixt will create it
11use the command \"save\" to apply changes on the file, or you will lose them
11the command \"exit\" closes tuixt (without saving!) and brings you to your home screen

string-array.name: tutorial_settings
string-array.item: 11T-UI is an highly customizable launcher. you can start using the command \"tuisettings\" which opens a text file called \"settings.txt\"

11as you will see it contains many lines of \"properties\" written with the scheme \"propertyName=propertyValue\". \ndo not ever edit propertyName, or you\'ll break that feature. just change propertyValue \nfor example:
01if you change #ff000000 (hexadecimal code) to #ffff0000 your background will become red
11aliases are one of the most powerful features of T-UI. you can assign a name to a command you use frequently and make it quicker to use \nstart using the command \"aliasfile\"

11this will open a file called \"alias.txt\" which already contains two aliases I created to show you how they work. \nthe scheme is easy to understand: aliasName=command \nyou can now create your personal aliases appending them to the file (one per line)
11you can use an alias typing its name in the input area and clicking enter. for example
